deIdi2b2.TEXT:
Record date: 2154-05-15
Team 3 Admission Note
PATIENT: Nathan Ishida
MRN: 8792076
ADMIT DATE: May 15, 2154
PCP: Norman Jewett, MD
ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:
CONTACT: Alice Zacharias , (582)157-6993
CODE STATUS: Full
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Dizziness and change in mental status
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Mr. Ishida is a 78 y/o, who p/w dizziness that began 2 to 3 weeks ago. The pt says the dizziness was worsened when he stood up to walk around; noting that it was particularly bad when he was standing and concentrating on a particular task such as shaving. The dizziness was alleviated by him lying down. He added that he began feeling dizzy during the storm last week when his drinking water was contaminated. He drank tap water until he was told it was undrinkable, then he stopped. He later developed diarrhea while not drinking any water and only having occasional Coca-cola beverages. During these 2 weeks of dizziness, Mr. Ishida notes he felt that he lost 3-4 days of his life, saying that he was either knocked out or unconscious. He came to this conclusion b/c his medication box was still full for the previous 3 days; supporting his reflection by saying he rarely ever misses his medication. Mr. Ishida states that the room was not spinning and said that his dizziness was more like “lightheadness.” He feels that his problems began when taking Tylenol- 2 weeks ago and cannot identify any other medication that is associated with his symptoms. Mr. Ishida says he’s never experienced any dizziness before, and hoped his symptoms would subside if he just stayed in bed. Mr. Ishida also described an increased pressure in his head, saying, “it felt as if my eyes and ears were going to explode.” Pt denies head trauma/falls, syncope, intoxication (from drugs or ETOH), or CP.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
General- No fatigue, lack of sleep, change in appetite, or weight gain/loss
Skin- No rashes, pruritus, bruising, or swelling
Head- No trauma, headache or syncope
Eyes- No change in vision, blurring, diplopia, irritation, photophobia, discharge, or spots/flashes
Ears- No change in hearing, pain, itching, buzzing, or ringing
Nose- No nasal congestion, runny nose, or epistaxis
Mouth/Throat- No oral ulcers, pain, dry mouth, dysphagia, sore throat, or swollen glands
Neck- No pain, discomfort
Breast- No pain, masses, or discharge
Lungs- No cough, SOB, DOE, orthopnea, PND, or pain
Cardiac- No CP or pressure or palpitations
Abdomen- Mild occasional constipation (resolved with laxative or stool softener). No pain, cramping, bloating, indigestion, or heartburn.
GU- No dysuria, polyuria, or nocturia. No discharge or pain in penis or groin.
MSK/Circulatory: No arthralgias, arthritis, cramps, stiffness, myalgias, tingling/numbness, or claudications
Endo- No heat/cold intolerance
Neuro- No shaking/tremors, memory changes, confusion, trouble reading, or speech changes. No paresthesias, numbness, or weakness.
Psych- No depression or sad mood.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
Major Illness/Surgeries- DM, CKD, HTN, Psoriasis, BPH, GERD/Barrett’s Esophagitis (1/2151), Gout, Sleep Apnea, s/p knee replacement surgery, cholecystectomy, appendectomy, tonsillectomy.
Medications
1. Acetylsalicylic Acid (Aspirin) 81 MG PO QD
2. Allopurinol 300 MG PO QD
3. Ammonium Lactate 12% Cream (Amlactin 12%) 1 APPLICATION TOP BID
4. Atenolol 25 MG PO QD
5. Dovonex (Calcipotriene 0.005%) TOP BID prn
6. Darifenacin Extended Release (Enablex) 15 MG PO QD
7. Docusate Sodium (Colace) 100 MG PO TID
8. Finasteride (Alopecia) (Proscar) 5 MG PO QD
9. Furosemide (Lasix) 40 MG PO QD
10. Lactulose 30 ML PO qD
11. Lisinopril 40 MG PO QD
12. Metformin 500 MG PO BID
13. Naproxen 375 MG PO BID prn toe pain
14. Omeprazole 20 MG PO BID
15. Sennosides (Senna Tablets) 2 TAB PO BID
16. Simvastatin 20 MG PO QHS
17. Valsartan (Diovan) 320 MG PO QD
Allergies- NKDA
Immunizations- Up-to-date
FAMILY HISTORY
Mr. Ishida’s mother died at 90 y/o and his father at 64 y/o due to a myocardial infarction. The Pt has 4 brothers, 3 daughters, and 2 sons; all in good health according to the pt.
SOCIAL HISTORY
Mr. Ishidas is an Visual Artist and former Exhibit Designer. He served in the government as a consultant, and denies any hazardous environmental exposures. His wife died 10 years ago of ovarian cancer and dearly misses her.
Diet- Mr. Ishidas describes his diet as “not as good as it should be.” He said he generally eats what he wants, eats out a lot and says he can eat a lot of “junk food.” He also said the only time he eats “well” is when he eat at his son’s or daughter’s house.
Smoking- Non-smoker
Alcohol- 2-3 bottles of beer per month. Pt doesn’t feel he needs to cut back.
Drugs- According to the pt he has used cocaine and crack as recent 5-6 years ago.
Sexual Hx- Mr. Ishidas is not currently sexually active.
PHYSICAL EXAM
Pt is an obese man with noticeable skin lesions (psoriasis) and alopecia. He looks well and jovial aside from his labored breathing.
VS: T: 97.8 BP: 122/60 HR: 92 RR: 18 SpO2: 97 on Room Air
General- No Acute Distress
HEENT - normocephalic, atraumatic; PERR, EOMI, sclerae anicteric, no conjunctival injection; poor dentition, oropharynx pink and moist w/o erythema, exudates, or lesions
Neck - no lymphadenopathy, normal thyroid without masses; JVP flat; carotid pulses 2+ bilaterally; no carotid bruits; the trachea is midline
Pulmonary – Symmetrical expansion. Normal percussion w/ no change in fremitus. Ronchi and wheezes bilaterally. No egophony or pectoriloquy.
Cardiac – irregularly irregular rhythm and rate; S1 and S2 normal; no murmurs, rubs or gallops; 2+ pulses in the extremities bilaterally
Abdomen - soft, non-distended; slight tenderness upon palpation of posterior abdomen; normal bowel sounds; no masses or hepatosplenomegaly
Extremity - warm and well-perfused; no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema
Neurology - CN II-XII grossly intact, good strength bilaterally, normal sensation bilaterally. Normal gait.
Skin – psoriatic lesions on elbows and thorax(anterior and posterior).
Mental status - alert and oriented to self, time, and place
LABORATORIES
142 113 58
-------------- 115
5.3 20.6 3.03
CA 9.2
PHOS 3.1
MG 2.3(H)
TBILI 0.4
DBILI 0.1
TP 7.1
ALB 4.1
GLOB 3.0(T)
AMY 83
LIPS 115(H)
WBC 5.5
RBC 4.11(L)
HGB 12.2(L)
HCT 38.3(L)
PLT 149(L)
MCV 93
ALT/SGPT 7(L)
AST/SGOT 9(L)
ALKP 70
CK-MB Negative
TROP-I Negative
MICROBIOLOGY
N/A
RADIOLOGICAL STUDIES
CXR: No pneumonia or other significant change from 11/26/52.
Head CT: No acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass lesion or territorial infarction identified. Chronic infarctions of the pons and right frontal operculum, unchanged.
EKG
Irregularly irregular rhythm, RBBB, abnormal ECG. PR< 200 ms, QRS< 110 ms, QTc>470
ASSESSMENT
Mr. Ishida is a 78 y/o M with h/o CKD, HTN, and NIDDM p/w sustained dizziness and altered mental status. Mr. Ishida is most likely currently in a volume depleted stated. He had diarrhea induced by the contaminated water from the storm and only maintained his hydration with a meager 2 or 3 bottles of Coca-cola over several days. This in combination with his output of fluid from diarrhea, his diuretic medication, and possible osmotic diuresis (increased serum glucose level from soda intake in a diabetic) could have shifted him into hypovolemia. Thus Mr. Ishida might have decrease effective arterial volume causing his BUN/Cr ratio to be elevated, indicating a prerenal process. Although BUN/Cr ratio is not >20, we can still assume that he has prerenal ARF considering his use of diuretics and h/o CKD which can decrease the sensitivity of BUN/Cr rations and FENa for assessing etiologies of renal failure. Mr. Ishida additionally uses NSAIDs (e.g. Naproxen), an ARB and an ACEI, all of which are associated with decreased intraglomerular pressure and renal vasoconstriction which can lead to prerenal ARF.
Intrinsic ARF is less likely considering he is not using any overtly nephrotoxic drugs (e.g. amphotericin, cisplatin, or aminoglycosides. Conversely, he is at an increased risk of cholesterol emboli given his h/o of hypercholesterolemia and vasculopathy.
Lastly, Mr. Ishida my have a postrenal ARF etiology considering his h/o BPH which could lead to obstruction of the outflow tract leading to increased pressures in the ureters flowing back up into the kidneys.
Mr. Ishida’s dizziness and altered mental status are both explained by ARF. Additional explanations of altered mental status are ruled out via the history and physical including intoxication, brain hemorrhagic, brain tumor, etc.
PLAN
#) Acture Renal Failure
-Continue fluids and hydration: 1L of IV saline over the next 24 hrs
-D/c naproxen use.
-Rule out Post-renal etiology: use ultrasound to assess the size of the bladder and ureters. If enlarged bladder and ureters are found the diagnosis is more likely postrenal ARF due to an enlarged prostate. Thus the patient should be assessed by Urology of possible partial prostatectomy.
#) DM
-Discontinue metformin due to possibility of metabolic acidosis and hospital drug interactions.
#) CAD
-Switch Atenlol to metoprolol given ARF
#) HTN
-Discontinue lisinopril, valsartan, furosemide until pt’s renal condition improves.
#) Gout
-D/C allopurinol until pt’s renal condition improves
#)Hypercholesterolemia
-Continue simvastatin as previously prescribed (Simvastatin 20 MG PO QHS)
#) Psoriasis
-Continue Ammonium Lactate 12% Cream and Calcipotriene 0.005% TOP BID prn
#)Benign Prostate Hypertrophy
-Continue Finasteride and darifenacin as previously prescribed.
_________________________
William Yates, MSIII
Pager #66612
